body:
I personally think this would make cursor configuration far too complex and it's actually less reliable than what we have today. Currently the width is calculated based on your font, so you can actually change the width by switching out your font with one that has metrics you prefer.

Setting the width in the config does not work, since it will prevent automatic scaling from working when you change your font size. The dimensions of cursors like the box also should never be anything different than the cell rects.

> Currently the width is calculated based on your font, so you can actually change the width by switching out your font with one that has metrics you prefer.

This is not entirely true, cursors is being calculated based on cell metrics, which you get from the font, so it has little to do with font tbh. We're not using underline metrics, etc, also if we use underline metrics, it could be hard to distinguish Underline cursor and Underline in some cases with small font.

>Setting the width in the config does not work, since it will prevent automatic scaling from working when you change your font size.

I agree with you here, it won't work, however if you use some base metrics like we have today and width will be percent of this setting, it'll work, so you'll be getting 20% thicker cursor, which will work, and limit it to let's say 100% of the base.

>The dimensions of cursors like the box also should never be anything different than the cell rects.

I absolutely agree with you here and I think we shouldn't touch block cursor at all.

So if I would propose such change, I'll likely do the following.
```yaml
cursor:
  style: [Block/Underline/Beam]

  Underline:
    # I doubt you want less width for this thing.
    height: 0.5 - 2
  Beam:
    height: 0.85 - 1.15 
    width: 0.5 - 2.
```

Those values for `height` and `width` are multiplier of our current base width/height, which should work well with scaling, etc.
What is `0.5 - 2` supposed to mean? If the problem is that people don't like the metrics we use, we should change our metrics not make this freely configurable.

People are different and could prefer our default cursor to a bit thicker one. The thing I've proposed is a multiplier to a default value metric with use, so it could scale +- nicely. That was just a template of configuration, you can use something more clear here. However some text editors are using similar approach to extra spacing for lines IIRC.

> People are different and could prefer our default cursor to a bit thicker one.

Is that the case? Is there any other terminal emulator, text editor, browser or application at all which allows configuring cursor width?

I still don't see what `0.5 - 2.` is supposed to do at all, but I think a multiplier will fundamentally not work well at all with scaling.

>I still don't see what 0.5 - 2. is supposed to do at all, but I think a multiplier will fundamentally not work well at all with scaling.

Multiplier will work, since your cursor width/height is a **percent** of the cell width, so when you multiply it, you multiply this percent, which works perfectly with scaling. E.g. with `2` for `Beam` cursor you'll occupy the `30%` of the cell, instead of default `15%`, so it should work just fine with scaling.

>Is that the case? Is there any other terminal emulator, text editor, browser or application at all which allows configuring cursor width?

Yes, [vscode](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/41169), [kitty](https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/conf.html#cursor-customization), [sublime](https://anlek.com/2014/01/sublime-text-editor-random-caret-height-and-width/), [iterm](https://gitlab.com/gnachman/iterm2/-/commit/c57437f4b78fc7a653a82b8aa95c94e7c7d5e523), [gtk](https://askubuntu.com/questions/284848/can-i-have-the-i-beam-mouse-cursor-more-visible-in-gtk3-apps).

> Multiplier will work, since your cursor width/height is a percent of the cell width

Yeah, but I'd assume for most people the problem is mostly around small fonts, not with larger fonts. So I can totally see that larger fonts will then suddenly have cursors that are "too big".

Also is `0.5 - 2.` supposed to be either `0.5`, `0.6`, ... `2.0`, or do you actually want to specify it as `0.5 - 2.`? The latter is definitely not going to happen.

>Also is 0.5 - 2. supposed to be either 0.5, 0.6, ... 2.0

Just a multiplier like `0.5` and this `0.5 - 2.` is the allowed range for them.

Note, that allowed range should be hardcoded in alacritty and can't be changed at all, so I was just proposing some values that could be of use, since larger, smaller doesn't make much sense most of the time.

> Just a multiplier like 0.5 and this 0.5 - 2. is the allowed range for them.

Ah, gotcha. Your notation was a bit confusing. Though I don't think I'd ever want to allow anything beyond `1.0`.

I'm still questioning the usecase of such a feature with a properly designed heuristic for cursor dimensions though. For example we'll never need to support changing I-Beam height, box, hollow box width/height or underline width. The only thing that we might want to change is the thickness of the cursor.

We already have a lot of metrics like underline/strikeout widths and cursor dimensions. So I feel like we should be able to determine these widths for the user without having to make them configurable. After all usually people don't complain about underline/strikeout thickness not being configurable either.

>We already have a lot of metrics like underline/strikeout widths and cursor dimensions. So I feel like we should be able to determine these widths for the user without having to make them configurable. After all usually people don't complain about underline/strikeout thickness not being configurable either.

I'm not sure that we actually can, since it's a preference in the end. Underline + strikeout are cosmetics, however cursor is an indicator, which should be visible. However I'm wonder what defaults are using other applications, e.g. gtk, since it seems like they use percent for cursor width as well as we're, but I feel like it's something larger than 0.15%.

>Ah, gotcha. Your notation was a bit confusing. Though I don't think I'd ever want to allow anything beyond 1.0.

My notation is a multiplier to our default percent, so in this notation range of `0.5 - 2` will allow Beam cursor width from `7.5%` of the cell, up to `30%` of the cell, since our cursor width is `15%` by default. 

>The only thing that we might want to change is the thickness of the cursor.

I agree here, let's focus on thickness, I really don't see a good benefit from a bit higher cursor, especially, that your cursor is higher than everything else by default for a normal characters. I'll also would propose generic cursor thickness for both underline and I-Beam cursors, like we have right now hard coded `15%` value, however one could want different thicknesses for both cursors(e.g. I'm fine with default thickness for Underline cursor on my system, but want a bit thicker beam cursor for vim).

I wonder if `(2 * thickness_of_underline).round()` will work though, but some fonts could have very strange underline metrics(extra thin), so I'm not sure that we should change approach with percent of the cell width.

> My notation is a multiplier to our default percent, so in this notation range of 0.5 - 2 will allow Beam cursor width from 7.5% of the cell, up to 30% of the cell, since our cursor width is 15% by default.

That just sounds more complicated than it needs to be tbh.

>  I'll also would propose generic cursor thickness for both underline and I-Beam cursors, like we have right now hard coded 15% value, however one could want different thicknesses for both cursors(e.g. I'm fine with default thickness for Underline cursor on my system, but want a bit thicker beam cursor for vim).

I think one thickness option would be more than enough. If people can't even make up their minds about how thick they want their cursors to be, I'm not sure if there's any satisfying them at all anyways.

> I wonder if (2 * thickness_of_underline).round() will work though

It wouldn't, since that would default to 2 pretty much every time. Which is an unacceptable minimum.

issue.title: Add option 'cursor.thickness' to set cursor thickness
